title: Building a blog with distill for R Markdown
description: This tutorial aims to provide you a step-by-step guide to build a web blog by using distill for R Markdown package.

author.name:
Dr. KAM Tin Seong,
Associate Professor of Information Systems (Practice)

contents:
Getting Started
Installing distill
Before you getting started, you need to install distill.
Start RStudio
At the Console window of RStudio, type the code chunk below:


install.packages("distill")



To learn more about what functions and features offer by distill, you should visit the homepage of distill for R Markdown at least once. The homepage provides a comprehensive discussion on the features and functions of distill.
Opening github and Netlify accounts
In this tutorial, github will be used to host the blog post and will be deploy via Netlify. To create an account, please visit their respective homepage below:
gihtub
netlify
Start a New Blog Project
To start a new blog project,
From the menu bar of RStudio, click on File -> New Project.

The New Project Wizard appears.

Click on New Directory -> Distill Blog.

Your screen should look similar to the screenshot below.

For Directory name:, type a name such as R4DSA. Avoid long name or/and name with spaces in between.
For Create project as subdirectory of:, navigate to a folder in your harddisk.
For Title:, provide a proper title for your blog (i.e. R for Data Science and Analytics).
Click on Create Project when you are ready.
Let us examine the Files window of RStudio as shown in the screenshot below. The home-directory is called R4DSA. It consists of the R4DSA.rproj file, the about.rmd file, the index.rmd file, the *_site.yml* file and two folders: *_posts* and *_site*.

Viewing the newly created blog page
Next, let us view the newly created blog page.
Click on _site folder.
Click on index.html.
Select View in Web Browser from the context menu
A web page appears on RStudio viewer as shown below.

Congratulations! Your first web blog has been built successfully.
Learning more about the blog content
Notice that the about.rmd and index.rmd are located at the home-directory. On the other hand, the welcome.rmd is located at *R4DSA/_posts/welcome* sub-directory as shown in the screenshot below.
The *_posts* folder contains all the R Markdown files we will use to create the blog posts.

The *_site* folder contains all the final html files and other libraries required to build the web page

Editing the _site.yml Page
From RStudio window, click on _site.yml tab.
You screen should look similar to the screenshot below.

The _site.yml is where we control the content of the blog that include the name, title, descriptive, and the navigation bars.
For name: type R4DSA.
To update the change, the code chunk below should be used.


rmarkdown::render_site()



Note: It is important to run the code chunk above when _site.yml is edited.
Notice that the title of the index page has changed to R4DSA instead of R for Data Science and Analytics.

Editing welcome.rmd
In this section, you will learn how to edit the welcome.rmd file and update its corresponding html page.
From RStudio window, click on welcome.rmd tab.
Your screen will look similar to the screenshot below.

This is the default welcome page. Let us edit the welcome page by using your own personal information similar to the example below.

Knit the document when the editing is completed.
The welcome page of the blog will look similar to the screenshot below.

Starting Git
In this section, you will learn how to start a git service in RStudio by using use_git() of usethis package.
 Note: Use the code chunk below to install usethis if it has yet to be installed in your computer.


install.packages("usethis")



Next, you will edit the code chunk below on RStudio Console.


usethis::use_git()



Press on Enter or Return key.
The follow message appears.

At this stage, we are not ready to commit the edition.
For Selection:, type 3.
Press on Enter key.
The follow message appears.

We are going to re-start RStudio.
For Selection:, type 1.
Press on Enter key.
The Switch Projects dialog window appears.

Click on Save button.
Notice that Git tab has been added on RStudio pane.

Your screen should look similar to the screenshot below.

We are going to commit all changes.
Click on the checkboxes in front of all the files.
Your screen should look similar to the screenshot below.

Click on Commit button.
Notice that we can not push the commit because we have yet to configured Github.
Configuring and Pushing to Github
In this section, you will learn how to configure Github and push the commit to Github.
At RStudio Console, type the command below:


usethis::use_github()



Press on Enter key to run the command.
Once the operation completed, the Gihtub webpage appears.

Publishing the Blog
In this section, you will learn how to publish the newly create blog on Netlify server.
Note: This sectgion assume that you have already create an account wit Netlify.
Login Netlify.
Your screen should look similar to the screenshot below.

Click on the button of New site from Git.
Your screen should look similar to the screenshot below.

Click on Github button.
Your screen should look similar to the screenshot below.

Scrolling down until Publish Directory appears.

At Publish directory, type -site.
When you are ready,
Click on Deploy site button.
Notice that Netlify will give a temporary and yet weird name.

You can change the name by using the Site settings option.
Click on Site settings button.
Your screen should look similar to the screenshot below.

Click on Change site name button.
The Change site name dialog window appears.

Give the site an easy to remember name (i.e r4dsa).
Click on Save button.
Notice that the blog page has a new name (i.e. r4dsa) now.

title: git in RStudio
description: This tutorial aims to provide you with the step-by-step guide on how to setup Git with R and RStudio.

author.name:
Dr. KAM Tin Seong,
Associate Professor of Information Systems (Practice)

contents:
Installing Git
To get started, you need to install Git in your computer. Additionally you will also need a GitHub account.
Download Git by using this link.
Installing Git. Note: It is important to provide the install Administrator right when installing Git.
On GitHub create yourself a free GitHub account.
Setup Git in RStudio
This step aims to tell RStudio where to find the Git installation.
Open RStudio and go to Tools -> Global Options…, click on Git/SVN.
Your screen should look similar to the screenshot below.

If there is not setting or the setting is at the wrong path,
click on the Browse button behind Git executable:.
Navigate to the correct folder where Git is installed. In general the path should be C:/Program Files/Git/bin/git.exe on 64bit machine on Windows OS.
Click on the Apply button to confirm the changes.
Click on OK button to close the window.
Restart RStudio, if it worked out you will find the Git icon on the top toolbar, as shown below.

Configure Git
In this step, you will configure Git and set your user name and email (the email address you used to register on GitHub). You can directly open the Git prompt from within RStudio.
Note: User name and email needs to be set only once.
Go to Tools -> Shell to open the Git Shell.
At the Shell command window, type the following commands.

Note: the user.name should be the user name on Github and the user.email should be the email address you used to create Github account.
Close Shell window.
Reference
If you are new to Git and Github, this link provides a lot of useful resources.
